title: Energy leaders can agree on one thing
text:
“Affordable, reliable energy matters to productivity and it matters to fairness,” he told the Summit, pointedly adding that consumers simply want to be sure they can turn on the lights “knowing that emission reductions aren’t adding to their costs”.

Energy Security Board chairwoman Kerry Schott. Louie Douvis

The only way to ensure that, in Taylor’s view, is by delivering more dispatchable to balance out the renewables boom. And in the short term, at least, that means baseload coal and gas-fired energy options remain crucial.

The threat of premature closure of baseload coal plants across the country – most notably AGL’s Liddell plant – without plans for like-for-like replacement is Taylor’s biggest fear. Which is why he believes extending the lives of those plants is crucial.

Kerry Schott also went out of her way to underscore her focus on the pain being felt by consumers, citing figures that showed energy bills leapt by about 120 per cent between September 2007 and September 2018, compared with a 20 per cent rise in wages and a 10 per cent rise in inflation.

Coal-fired plants are 'dinosaurs'

She also warned that the investments required for changes in transmission and distribution networks would need to be borne at least in part by these same consumers.

But Schott warned that just as our transmission and distribution networks are no longer fit for purpose, coal-fired power plants aren’t the answer to the dispatchable power gap.

Advertisement

“What we need in the market is energy that is both firm and flexible,” she said, pointing to the “duck curve” that often sees demand for coal-fired power plummet between 11am and 4pm in South Australia and Queensland as renewables kick in during the day, and then surge again as the supply of renewables falls away in the evening.

“[Coal-fired plants] are not flexible at ramping up or ramping down – they are dinosaurs in that sense,” she said.

Calabria used his speech to call repeatedly for incentives to encourage investment in flexible dispatchable power options. But exactly what those incentives might look like isn’t clear.

Government intervention, such as underwriting new generation, is an option, but one the market seems sceptical of, given the size of the investment needed. Reliability obligations could play a role and emissions intensity targets are another option, but not one Taylor is likely to embrace.

It’s another question for the sector to endlessly debate.
description: At the AFR's National Energy Summit on Wednesday, Angus Taylor, Kerry Schott and Frank Calabria found a rare point of agreement.
